10.author: cb
text: Even though previous judge has been determined to be a dick this does not fix rule 204.

2.author: aw
text: The chronology of 214 requires a dispute to be raised before people agreeing or disagreeing with the judgement.

15.author: cb
text: Yes, the would be a consequence of the second Judgement of PO 302.3, assuming it is not overruled. In particular, if not overruled, it will release Proposal 302 to come into effect.

5.author: aw
text: No rule speculates the need for a PhD to judge something the average reception student could deduce.

11.author: at
text: Since the question is not in English, I will judge on two potential interpretations. Firstly, it is not required by 214 for a Judge to be independent. Secondly, whatever independent means, no Judge in the possession of Chris will be considered independent.

7.author: cb
text: Rule 204 is entirely void as it conflicts with an immutable rule.

13.author: at
text: Rule 204 is in conflict with Rule 111. This takes into account that the actions of players have been influenced by these rules (see PO 301.3) As per Rule 112, Rule 204 is “entirely void”. This is consistent with the Judgement of PO 301.2.

0.author: aw
text: Due to the wording of 112 'For the purpose of this rule a proposal to transmute an immutable rule does not "conflict" with that immutable rule.' I judge that any rule that questions the remit or position of another rule is in conflict with that rule. Therefore by 112 a mutable rule cannot supercede an immutable rule.

9.author: cb
text: Any rule change that amends, enacts or repeals another rule is immediately passed as here the mechanism for rule changes is governed by the empty set of rules. So in particular any completed and uncompleted vote means the rules is adopted.

14.author: dmcc
text: Given that Rule 204 is void, no rule explicitly provides a mechanism that rule changes may be adopted. All attempts to enact a rule are subject to Rule 118. Specifically, it states that we may change the rules only when “explicitly or implicitly” allowed. Thus, this Judgement must decide whether a mechanism for a new rule is implicit within the remaining rules. Rule 104 specifies that a rule change will be adopted “if and only if they receive the required number of votes”. This implies the existence of a notion of a required number of votes, and given this, in conjunction with Rules 107, 113 a mechanism to change the rules. Finally, the notion of required number of votes is not “prohibited or regulated” in the sense of Rule 118, so I am free to state that the required number of votes is 0, until such a rule is brought in that defines the number of required votes

4.author: aw
text: It shall be 'entirely void' meaning that the rule as a whole is void.

3.author: aw
text: If any number of rules change your method of play due to them being in conflict, then they are 'in conflict' as in the sense of the rules.

8.author: cb
text: Rule 204 being void means one cannot enact or amend rules via voting. Only transmutation of immutable rules to mutable rules is allowed as this is covered by rule 111 which is valid.

1.author: aw
text: Whilst true, nothing within the rules requires sound mind.

12.author: at
text: Only the first reply in the correct format, referencing the Point of Order, constitutes judgement. Any subsequent message or messages not in the correct format are void. Such messages are irrelevant and not considered edits.
